conclusion: To determine when the two cars collide, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs of Car A and Car B.
The v-t graph shows Car A starting at 25 m/s and Car B starting at 15 m/s, both decelerating linearly.
Car A starts at 25 m/s and decelerates at a rate of 2 m/s².
Car B starts at 15 m/s and decelerates at a rate of 3 m/s².
For Car A, the time to reach the point where they would have avoided colliding is calculated as \( t = \frac{v_f - v_i}{a} = \frac{0 - 25}{-2} = 12.5 \) seconds.
For Car B, the time to reach the point where they would have avoided colliding is calculated as \( t = \frac{v_f - v_i}{a} = \frac{0 - 15}{-3} = 5 \) seconds.
The time it takes for Car A to reach the point where they would have avoided colliding is 12.5 seconds.
The time it takes for Car B to reach the point where they would have avoided colliding is 5 seconds.
The two cars collide after 12.5 seconds of braking.
